sanskrit:
आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः।
मातुलाः श्वशुराः पौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा॥
transliteration:
ācāryāḥ pitaraḥ putrās tathaiva ca pitāmahāḥ |
mātulāḥ śvaśurāḥ pautrāḥ śyālāḥ sambandhinas tathā ||
translation: Teachers, fathers, sons, and also grandfathers; maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives.
commentary:
In this verse, Arjuna continues his enumeration of the various relatives and respected elders arrayed on the battlefield. He lists teachers (ācāryāḥ) such as Dronacharya, fathers and father-figures, sons, grandfathers like Bhishma, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other family connections (sambandhinaḥ). This detailed cataloging reveals the depth of Arjuna's emotional turmoil as he recognizes that victory in this war would require killing those bound to him by blood, marriage, and sacred bonds of learning.

The verse emphasizes the complex web of relationships that characterized ancient Indian society, where duties toward family, teachers, and kinsmen were considered sacred obligations. Arjuna's listing of these relationships is not merely descriptive but represents his growing awareness of the moral complexity of the situation. The mention of ācāryāḥ (teachers) is particularly significant, as the guru-disciple relationship was considered one of the most sacred bonds, and the thought of raising weapons against one's teacher would have been especially horrifying to Arjuna. This verse sets the stage for Arjuna's complete breakdown and his subsequent refusal to fight, which becomes the catalyst for Krishna's teachings in the subsequent chapters.
speaker: Arjuna
